contentrichtext.text: {{More footnotes|date=July 2010}} {{Infobox political party |name = Rhodesian Front |native_name = Rhodesiese Front |lang1 = English |name_lang1 = Rhodesian Front |lang2 = Afrikaans |name_lang2 = Rhodesiese Front |logo = [[File:Flag of the Rhodesian Front.svg|252px]] |leader = [[Winston Field]] ''(1962–1964)''<br> [[Ian Douglas Smith|Ian Smith]] ''(1964-1981)'' |founded = March 1962 |dissolved = {{End date|1981|06|06}} |successor =[[Republican Front]] |headquarters = [[Harare|Salisbury]]<br/>{{flagcountry|Southern Rhodesia}} <small>(''de jure'')</small><br/>{{flagcountry|Rhodesia}} <small>(''de facto'')</small> |colorcode = white |membership = |ideology = [[Conservatism]] <br> [[White minority rule]]<br>[[Rhodesia]]n [[nationalism]]<br>[[Unilateral Declaration of Independence|Rhodesian independence]] |position = [[Right-wing]] |national = |colours = [[Purple]] |seats1_title = |seats1 = <!-- {{Infobox political party/seats|seats_won|total_seats|hex=#ff0000}} --> |seats2_title = |seats2 = |symbol = |colorcode =Purple |country = Rhodesia }} {{Politics of Rhodesia}} The '''Rhodesian Front''' ('''RF''') was a [[political party]] in [[Rhodesia]] (or [[Southern Rhodesia]]) when the country was under [[white minority rule]]. Led first by [[Winston Field]], and, from 1964, by [[Ian Smith]], the Rhodesian Front was the successor to the [[Dominion Party]], which was the main opposition party in Southern Rhodesia during the [[Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland|Federation]] period. The RF was formed in March 1962 by whites opposed to any immediate change to black [[majority rule]]. It won power in the [[Southern Rhodesia general election, 1962|general election]] that December. In successive elections (in which 50 of the 66 parliamentary seats were reserved for A-Roll voters, who had to meet a higher standard of qualifications, increasing the proportion of white Africans who came under this roll) between 1964 and 1979, the RF was returned to office, with a large majority, with Smith as Prime Minister. The RF had fifteen founding principles, which included the preservation of each racial group's right to maintain its own identity, the preservation of 'proper standards' through a policy of advancement through merit, the maintenance of the [[Land reform in Zimbabwe|Land Apportionment Act]], which formalized the racial imbalance in the ownership and distribution of land, opposition to compulsory [[racial integration]], job protection for white workers, and maintenance of the government's right to provide separate amenities for different races. Following the elections leading to the country's independence in 1980, as the Republic of Zimbabwe, the RF won all 20 parliamentary seats reserved for whites in the power-sharing agreement that it had forged. On June 6, 1981, the party changed its name to the Republican Front, and on July 21, 1984 it became the [[Conservative Alliance of Zimbabwe]]. Eleven of its twenty parliamentarians defected over the following four years, but the party again won 15 of the 20 parliamentary seats reserved for whites in the [[Zimbabwe parliamentary election, 1985|1985 election]]. In 1986, the CAZ opened its membership to Zimbabweans of all races. In 1987 the ruling government abolished all reserved seats for whites.
